none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from George Curtis, July 26, 1885
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from George Curtis, July 26, 1885
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 20 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: Personal letter from George W. Curtis, professor of agriculture at Texas Agricultural and Mechanical College, to Louis L. McInnis, the college treasurer, dated July 26, 1885. Curtis discusses his recent travels, his indecision about accepting faculty housing, domestic arrangements and household help, and expresses interest in attending the State Grange meeting. The letter reflects both professional collegial concerns and personal domestic matters of a faculty family during the early development of Texas A&M.

body.value:
[Header]

Agricultural and Mechanical College
—:— OF TEXAS. —:—

Department Agriculture and Horticulture
[Image: Star]
GEO. W. CURTIS, B. S. A.

CORRESPONDENCE
ON MATTERS RELATING TO COLLEGE
PROPER SHOULD BE ADDRESSED TO
THE CHAIRMAN.
WE INVITE CONSULTATION WITH
THE HEAD OF THIS DEPARTMENT; ON
ANY AND ALL TOPICS RELATING TO
AGRICULTURE AND HORTICULTURE.
WE MAKE A SPECIALTY OF FINE
STOCK.

FACULTY.
CHAIRMAN :
H. H. DINWIDDIE.
TREASURER :
L. L. McINNIS.
J. R. COLE. R. WIPPRECHT;
W. L. BRINGHURST,
GEO. W. CURTIS,
R. H. WHITLOCK,
R. F SMITH.

Anamosa, Iowa
College Station, Brazos Co., Texas, July 26" 1883.

My Dear Prof.: — Yours of 7/17/83
found here on my return from Inde-
pendence. where we have been visiting
for the past week. My! we were
about used up running around
so much. Someway it tires
me more to travel on the cars
than to work all day and Florence
agrees to Ditto. I dont know
about the girl – The one we spoke
of last year cannot come now
as she is a mother. and I do not
know of another one whom
I would recommend. Cole wants
to sell me his stuff which he
has put around his house
but I dont want any such
property. I wrote him that I
would pay him interest on his
investment yearly if I should
occupy the house; but I will
tell you Professor – we hardly
know whether to take the house

**Transcription Process Deep Dive** Okay, here's how I'm approaching this task. First, I'm setting the stage: I'm a transcriptionist, my job is to accurately reproduce the text from this image. The ground rules are pretty straightforward: go top to bottom, left to right, preserve everything – spelling, punctuation, even the line breaks – as closely as possible. If the handwriting's fuzzy, I use the "[?]" notation. Layout matters, so I'm paying attention to headings, footers, and any special formatting in the source. And the only tools I have at my disposal are HTML tags listed in the prompt; no fancy tricks. The sole output is the transcription itself. Now, let's dissect the image. It's a handwritten letter on official letterhead. The letterhead gives me a lot to work with. It's from the "Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas." There's a curved sub-header "Department Agriculture and Horticulture", a star graphic, and columns. The left column says "CORRESPONDENCE" along with specific instructions in fine print; the right one lists "FACULTY" members. And there's a name at the bottom: "GEO. W. CURTIS, B. S. A." Then comes the handwriting itself. It's cursive and slanted, which I need to get as clear as possible. The location is handwritten "Anamosa, Iowa" *over* the printed "College Station, Brazos Co., Texas,". The date is "July 26" 1883." The salutation is "My Dear Prof.:" and then the main text. I need to make sure I transcribe everything precisely. I'm thinking about the transcription in stages. First, the header section. I need to get the main title ("Agricultural and Mechanical College"), the subtitle ("OF TEXAS"), and then the contents of the columns right. The left column, "CORRESPONDENCE", is important: "ON MATTERS RELATING TO COLLEGE PROPER SHOULD BE ADDRESSED TO THE CHAIRMAN." etc. The right column, with the FACULTY list, requires careful transcription of names: H. H. Dinwiddie, L. L. McInnis, J. R. Cole, R. Wipprecht, W. L. Bringhurst, Geo. W. Curtis, R. H. Whitlock, and R. F. Smith. And finally, the name at the bottom, GEO. W. CURTIS, B. S. A. Next, I look at the dateline. The "College Station..." text is crossed out, but I'll transcribe it. The handwriting above it says "Anamosa, Iowa". It is more important than the printed text. The date is "July 26" 1883". The salutation is straightforward: "My Dear Prof.: —". Now the body. Paragraph by paragraph: * "Yours of 7/17/83" * "found here on my return from Independence," * "where we have been visiting" * "for the past week." * "My! we were" * "about used up running around" * "so much. Someway it tires" * "me more to travel on the cars" * "than to work all day and Florence agrees to Ditto." * "I dont know about the girl – The one we spoke" * "of last year cannot come now as she is a mother. and I do not" * "know of another one whom I would recommend." That's the first paragraph. The second paragraph: * "Cole wants" * "to sell me his stuff which he" * "has put around his house" * "but I dont want any such" * "property. I wrote him that I" * "would pay him interest on his" * "investment yearly if I should" * "occupy the house; but I will tell you Professor – we hardly" * "know whether to take the house" Now comes the formatting: I'll use `

[1885, July 26]

Agricultural and Mechanical College

--- OF TEXAS. ---

| | | | | :--- | :---: | :--- | | CORRESPONDENCE

ON MATTERS RELATING TO COLLEGE
PROPER SHOULD BE ADDRESSED TO
THE CHAIRMAN.
WE INVITE CONSULTATION WITH
THE HEAD OF THIS DEPARTMENT, ON
ANY AND ALL TOPICS RELATING TO
AGRICULTURE AND HORTICULTURE.
WE MAKE A SPECIALTY OF FINE
STOCK. | Department Agriculture and Horticulture

★

GEO. W. CURTIS, B. S. A. | FACULTY.

CHAIRMAN :
H. H. DINWIDDIE.
TREASURER :
L. L. McINNIS.
J. R. COLE. R. WIPPRECHT,
W. L. BRINGHURST,
GEO. W. CURTIS,
R. H. WHITLOCK,
R. F. SMITH. |

College Station, Brazos Co., Texas, ..................... 188

[Margin: L.L. McI
2]

or not. We dont like the
house in the first place and
it is terribly used up from
having so many youthful
scions growing up around
It is not like Dinwiddie's and of course there
would be no prospect of getting
Dinwiddie to change
Then in the second place
we have our rooms comfortably
fixed where we are and if we
change it will cost a good deal
to fix up the house so as to be
habitable and then to get outfit to
start to housekeeping. I declare
I dont know what to do. I
know I should like it better
to keep house: but it would
throw more care & responsibility
on Mrs. C. Well we are going
to ruminate on it any way
and if we can find one girl
who is willing to go for you we will
engage her subject to your
approval by letter whether we
go to housekeeping or not.

**Transcription Analysis and Refinement**

Okay, here's what I've got. I've received an image of a handwritten letter on official letterhead from the Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas, and my task is to produce a transcription of the text, focusing on accuracy and layout. I've broken down my process into several stages.

First, the *header*. I carefully analyzed the header elements, noting the handwritten date "[1885, July 26]" in pencil at the top right, the main title "Agricultural and Mechanical College," the subtitle "--- OF TEXAS. ---," and the departmental information. I used a Markdown table to preserve the intended column layout for the correspondence rules, faculty list, and the central department information. I made sure to capture all the text, even the small print and the graphics, like the star. I looked up to compare the faculty member's names with the image to ensure accuracy.

Next, I turned my attention to the *dateline* and the *body text*. I observed the dateline, "College Station, Brazos Co., Texas, ... 188..." and the marginal note "L.L. McI" with a "2" underneath, suggesting it's page 2 of a letter. The body text presented a few challenges. I paid close attention to the handwriting, noting the cursive script. I'm going to transcribe everything faithfully, including any insertions or strikethroughs (though the prompts limits my ways to address it). I made sure to capture the original text, interpret the deletions, and try to preserve the spirit of the writer's intent, given the restrictions. The guidelines said I should "Preserve original spelling... Interpret handwritten text".

Here's how I handled specific text features:

*   **Strikethroughs:** I've been given a restricted list of HTML tags I can use. I can't directly use tags like `<s>` or `<del>` to denote strikethroughs. However, I can still transcribe the text as it's written. I've re-examined and carefully considered the crossed-out words in line 1 ("We dont [crossed out word] like the"). I'm choosing to transcribe the text as "We dont like the", since that seems to be the final intent.

*   **Insertions:** I've noted any inserted words or phrases (e.g., "and" inserted into a sentence). I've transcribed these as they appear in the text. I will use only text, in order, from the image.

*   **Marginalia:** The "L.L. McI" and "2" notes (likely page 2 indicator) are transcribed accurately. The handwriting in the marginalia is not legible but will be kept.

*   **Questionable words:** I carefully examined words that were potentially unclear, such as "ruminate" or words with corrections, using context and letter comparison. Line 22 "to ruminate" caused me some doubt, but through context and letter comparison, I verified this. I decided it could be.

Regarding the *layout*, I'll use Markdown to represent the header structure (table for columns) and paragraphs for the body. I will stick to allowed tags to maintain readability.

I've also made a few linguistic observations:

*   The "scions" reference indicates the writer is talking about many children.
*   The "Mrs. C" likely refers to Mrs. Curtis, as the letter is written by "GEO. W. CURTIS".
*   The letter mentions H. H. Dinwiddie, the chairman, and L. L. McInnis, the Treasurer.

The final transcription is designed to be as accurate as possible, within the given constraints, and to reflect the original text's nuances and layout.

[Header]

[1885, July 26]

Agricultural and Mechanical College
⚬⚬⚬⚬ OF TEXAS. ⚬⚬⚬⚬

CORRESPONDENCE
ON MATTERS RELATING TO COLLEGE PROPER SHOULD BE ADDRESSED TO THE CHAIRMAN.
WE INVITE CONSULTATION WITH THE HEAD OF THIS DEPARTMENT, ON ANY AND ALL TOPICS RELATING TO AGRICULTURE AND HORTICULTURE.
WE MAKE A SPECIALTY OF FINE STOCK.

Department Agriculture and Horticulture
[Graphic: Star]

FACULTY.
CHAIRMAN :
H. H. DINWIDDIE.
TREASURER :
L. L. McINNIS.
J. R. COLE. R. WIPPRECHT,
W. L. BRINGHURST,
GEO. W. CURTIS,
R. H. WHITLOCK,
R. F SMITH.

GEO. W. CURTIS, B. S. A.

[/Header] [Margin: L McI 3]

College Station, Brazos Co., Texas, ________________ 188_

You may appreciate our indecision in the matter. So many things are to be considered

Many thanks for your help in trying to get part of my expenses paid to Washington Of course I do not know how it happened but I think I can guess pretty closely When we meet we can talk some things over.

Am glad you are going to attend St. Grange. watch things carefully, wish I could be there too: hope you may be able to establish the belief that we have something else at in sympathy with the Grange College, besides a Chairman. Well I am going to church - Can you say as much?

Mrs Curtis joins in Love to "Miss McI" and kindest wishes for all of our friends at Forest

Ever truly
Geo. W. Curtis

**Letter Transcription Analysis: A Deep Dive** Alright, let's break this down. My goal here is to get a clean transcription of this letter, making sure to capture the nuances of the handwriting and layout, while also paying close attention to the historical context. First, the letterhead. It's the "Agricultural and Mechanical College OF TEXAS," with the pencil date "[1885, July 26]" penciled in at the top. The organization of the letterhead text is as follows: * **Left Column (Correspondence)** is where we have: "CORRESPONDENCE," then some guidelines, "ON MATTERS RELATING TO COLLEGE PROPER SHOULD BE ADDRESSED TO THE CHAIRMAN," followed by "WE INVITE CONSULTATION WITH THE HEAD OF THIS DEPARTMENT, ON ANY AND ALL TOPICS RELATING TO AGRICULTURE AND HORTICULTURE," and finally, "WE MAKE A SPECIALTY OF FINE STOCK." * **Center Graphic:** A graphic or image with "Department Agriculture and Horticulture" in an arc over a star. This likely signifies the specific department. * **Right Column (Faculty)** has the "FACULTY" heading, then the names: "CHAIRMAN : H. H. DINWIDDIE.", "TREASURER : L. L. McINNIS.", "J. R. COLE. R. WIPPRECHT,", "W. L. BRINGHURST,", "GEO. W. CURTIS,", "R. H. WHITLOCK,", "R. F SMITH.". * **Bottom Center:** "GEO. W. CURTIS, B. S. A." – his signature and designation. Now, let's dig into the handwritten portion. The standard format: * **Date Line:** "College Station, Brazos Co., Texas, _______________ 188_" – the year is incomplete. Note that the date at the top is very likely the completed date. The blank space indicates it wasn't filled in at the time. * **Margin Note:** "L McI" and "3" – this is important. "L McI" likely relates to L. L. McInnis, the Treasurer listed on the letterhead. It's a filing reference, or an indicator of priority. * **Body of the Letter:** * The first paragraph, the writer is saying, "You may appreciate our indecision in the matter. So many things are to be considered." * Next, "Many thanks for your help in trying to get part of my expenses paid to Washington Of course I do not know how it happened but I think I can guess pretty closely When we meet we can talk some things over." There is a reference to some help, and "Washington" (I believe it's capitalized). * Then, "Am glad you are going to attend St. Grange. watch things carefully, wish I could be there too: hope you may be able to establish the belief that we have something else at in sympathy with the Grange College, besides a Chairman. Well I am going to church - Can you say as much?" This is interesting. "St. Grange" could be "State Grange". But, I will record the "St.", or State, or St. Grange, given that it's likely an abbreviated reference to an agricultural organization or meeting. The "in sympathy with the Grange" text is inserted. * Finally, there is "Mrs Curtis joins in Love to "Miss McI" and kindest wishes for all of our friends at Forest Ever truly Geo. W. Curtis". The reference to "Miss McI" is in quotes. Given the "L McI" filing note, it is probably in reference to L.L. McInnis. Or maybe a relative or friend of Mr. McInnis. "Forest" is likely a place, or friend. Now the transcription itself: ```html [Header] [1885, July 26] Agricultural and Mechanical College OF TEXAS.

WE INVITE CONSULTATION WITH THE HEAD OF THIS DEPARTMENT, ON ANY AND ALL TOPICS RELATING TO AGRICULTURE AND HORTICULTURE.

FACULTY.
